Muller asks tuition hike to $3000
By RICHARD WARING
Tuition will rise at least $300
next September if a proposal by
President Muller is approved by
the Board of Trustees at their
meeting this month.
Muller told a Faculty General
Assembly meeting Friday that he
would propose a tuition rise of at
least $300. He indicated that he
was confident the Board would
approve his proposal.
He also stated, "I will insist
that any tuition rise be
accompanied by a rise in
graduate and undergraduate
student aid."
In other business, the General
Assembly turned down, by a
29-29 vote, after many faculty
left the meeting, a proposal
by Dr. Philip Hartman,
Mathematics, to reform the
Academic Council election
process.
His proposal asked that the
AC election process require two
preferential ballots instead of
one, to nominate candidates for
appointment by the president,
that the length of a term be

decreased to four from five years,
and that the length of time a
faculty member must wait
between terms be increased from
one to three years.
Concerning the tuition rise,
Muller stated that he saw no way
the University could meet its
budget gap and return to a
balanced budget by 1974, as
mandated by the Trustees,
without a tuition rise. If this cost
rise is approved by the board,
Muller, noted, no further tuition
rise should be necessary before
1975. The University has a $1
million deficit budgeted for the
current year, but it is expected to
come in as much as $250,000
below that figure.
"We should have a balanced
budget by 1974 with this
increase, barring any future
financial disasters," Muller
commented.
Commenting further on his
concern for the University's fiscal
situation, Muller revealed that he
plans to ask the Finance
Committee of the Board to seek
a balance between growth in

Hopkins investment portfolio
and annual yield in dollars
available for general use.

When he took over as President of the University for
the second time in April, 1971, former President
Milton S. Eisenhower announced that there would be
no tuition increases during his term as interim
president. He did state upon his retirement that his
successor would almost certainly have to impose a rise
in tuition. True to that prediction, Steven Muller
announced last Friday that he would ask the Board of
Trustees for an increase in tuition of at least $300 at
their meeting this month in Williamsburg, Virginia.
While it is obvious that the University needs to
obtain more money from some source in order to
balance its budget by 1974, there is some question as
to why the students should be expected to provide the
bulk of the money. A little quick arithmetic shows
that 2200 students all paying, from some source, $300
more in tuition will provide $660,000 in additional
funds, very close to the total expected budget deficit
of $750,000 for the Arts and Sciences division this
year. This increase will place a real hardship on the
already hard-pressed student, especially the junior or
sophomore who cannot transfer to another, less
expensive institution before next year, who will have
no choice except to pay the higher rate, or drop out of
school altogether.
Unless President Muller can come up with facts and
figures to back up his proposal at tonight's Student
Council meeting, there is no reason students should be
expected to pay anything more than $2700 for a year
of a Hopkins education.
